author: sky.cactus
content: Sure:  ZK Rollups are better, but harder to build.  Optimistic Rollups are worse, but easier to build.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> The second advantage of zkRollups is the absence of a withdrawal period.
> This advantage is also a curse. You might know that Optimism recently paid the largest bug bounty in history (2M$) for an infinite money bug.
> But if the bug had been exploited, the withdrawal period would have allowed us to rollback the chain to mitigate the damage.
(╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻
(from that thread) This is only a viable strategy if you have a centralized/permissioned system with an intentional delay baked in and the ability to *rewrite history*.  You can build such a system with a zkRollup just fine, *or* you can build an actually permissionless system with a zkRollup.

author: killari.
content: Optimistic rollups can be bit cheaper as you could just use layer 1 for storage and you don't need proofs at all.

author: sky.cactus
content: How does that make them cheaper?

author: killari.
content: you just store data with no computation

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, no need to validate a proof?

author: sky.cactus
content: That is true, but it fades with scale to the point of inconsequentiality.
